The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 allows certain seniors who do not itemize their deductions to claim a deduction for state and local real property taxes. The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 allows eligible senior taxpayers to deduct state and local real property taxes that exceed the amount distributed from the senior citizen real property tax account. The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 defines an eligible senior taxpayer as someone who is at least 65 years old and has a modified adjusted gross income below $30,000 for the taxable year. The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 defines an eligible senior taxpayer as someone who is at least 65 years old and has a modified adjusted gross income below $60,000 for the taxable year. Modified adjusted gross income is determined by the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the year, excluding certain sections, and after applying specific tax provisions. The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 defines eligible senior taxpayers as those aged 65 or older with a modified adjusted gross income below $60,000 for the taxable year. SEC. 222 of the Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 establishes Senior Citizen Real Property Tax Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code. Amounts are subject to inflation adjustments, and any adjusted amount not a multiple of $100 will be rounded down. The Seniors Real Property Tax Relief Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash contributions made to a senior citizen real property tax account, with a maximum deduction of $2,000 per year. A senior citizen real property tax account is a trust created for paying qualified property tax expenses for the beneficiary. The trust must meet specific requirements, including accepting contributions only in cash, not exceeding $2,000 per year, and not accepting contributions after the beneficiary reaches age 59 1/2. The trustee must be a bank or demonstrate compliance with the trust requirements. The trustee must be a bank or demonstrate compliance with the trust requirements. No part of the trust assets will be invested in life insurance contracts, and the assets shall not be commingled with other property except in a common trust fund or common investment fund. Qualified property tax expenses refer to real property taxes on the beneficiary's principal residence. The term 'account beneficiary' refers to the individual for whom the senior citizen real property tax account was established. Rules similar to those in Section 219(d)(2) apply for this section. Tax Treatment of Senior Citizen Real Property Tax Accounts:
- Accounts are exempt from taxation unless they cease to be such accounts.
- Accounts may be subject to taxes under section 511.
- Rules similar to Section 219(d)(2) apply for account beneficiaries. Tax Treatment of Distributions from Senior Citizen Real Property Tax Accounts:
- Distributions made before age 59 1/2 increase tax by 50%.
- Distributions made after age 59 1/2 increase tax by 25%. The increase in tax for distributions made after age 59 1/2 is 25%. This increase is in lieu of any inclusion in gross income. Amounts used for qualified property tax expenses are excluded from gross income. The distribution of funds after the death of the account beneficiary or due to disability is exempt from certain tax rules. If the distribution is made to a senior citizen real property tax account or individual retirement plan, or if the beneficiary is disabled, the tax on the distribution will be determined differently. The amendment includes a new subparagraph for failure to provide reports on senior citizen real property tax accounts under section 6693(a) of the Code.
